Yes, many of these solutions are already being implemented by farmers across the world, to address the long-term effects of climate change on agriculture. 

For example, sustainable land management practices such as conservation tillage, cover cropping, and agroforestry have been adopted by farmers worldwide to promote soil health and reduce erosion. Similarly, the development of climate-resilient crops is ongoing, with some crops already available in the market like drought-tolerant maize and rice varieties.

Efforts are also being made to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture, for example, by the use of reduced tillage and fertilizer management practices. Moreover, water-saving techniques have been implemented in various regions to help farmers adapt to unreliable rainfall and drought conditions.

Market-based solutions such as carbon credits for agriculture, are still in the initial stages of development, but have been adopted by some farmers worldwide as a way to monetize their sustainable land management practices.

In summary, while the adoption of some of these solutions may still be limited in some parts of the world, there are farmers who are already taking steps to address the long-term effects of climate change on agriculture.
